column4: These data show wildfire potential in the conterminous United States, Alaska, and Hawaii based on the 2020 version of the Wildfire Hazard Potential (WHP) map by the U.S. Forest Service Fire, Fuel, and Smoke Science Program. Original data are mapped at a 270-meter grid. Grid cells are classified on a relative scale from 1 to 5 for very low (1), low (2), moderate (3), high (4), and very high (5). The 2020 version was built by integrating national spatial datasets of wildfire burn probability and fire intensity from LANDFIRE 2014 using the Large Fire Simulator (FSim), as well as spatial fuels and vegetation data from LANDFIRE 2014 and point locations of past fire occurrence from 1992 to 2015.
column6: U.S. Department of Agriculture, U.S. Forest Service

column4: These data show coastal change projections for the year 2050, based on existing measurements of shorelines and rates of erosion or accretion. Original data come from the USGS Coastal and Marine Resources Program and is archived here. Data have been processed into box-like units showing a measured rate of erosion for each transect perpendicular to the shoreline. The box-like units for each transect were dissolved into a common polygon that identifies areas that are susceptible to coastal erosion by 2050. These areas are classified as "5" in our relative ranking scale of 1 to 5. Data are available for the conterminous United States and Hawaii.
column6: U.S. Geological Survey, National Assessment of Shoreline Change project
column8: https://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2006/1251/#gis (CA); https://doi.org/10.5066/F78P5XNK (Gulf of Mexico); https://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2011/1009/data.html (Hawaii); https://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2010/1119/data_catalog.html (New England and Mid-Atlantic coast); https://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2012/1008/html/data.html (Pacific NW); https://doi.org/10.5066/F74X55X7 (SE Atlantic coast)

column4: These data show the chance of damaging earthquake shaking in the United States from naturally occurring earthquakes in the next 50 years. Original raster data come from researchers with the USGS Earthquake Hazards Program. Numerical values for the chance of a damaging earthquake were reclassified into the following 5 relative bins to note likelihood: very low (less than 4% chance), low (4 to 19%), moderate (19-36%), high (36-75%), and very high (greater than 75%). Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, Hawaii, and Puerto Rico.
column6: U.S. Geological Survey, Earthquake Hazards program
column9: Chance of Damaging Earthquake Shaking in the Next 50 years

column4: These data show flood hazard zones contained in the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) National Flood Hazard Layer (NFHL), which is a geospatial database that contains current effective flood hazard data to support the National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP). The NFHL is designed only to support the NFIP; therefore, its coverage on DOI and tribal lands of interest is limited due to the lack of flood insurance on federal lands. Polygonal NFHL data were acquired via the FEMA Map Service Center. Based on FEMA guidance, flood-hazard zones were classified as low to moderate flood risk for areas delineated as a 0.2-percent-annual-chance (or 500-year) flood and as high flood risk for floodways and areas with 1-percent annual chance (or 100-year) flood. Areas are noted as "susceptible to flooding" in this map if they are identified as high flood risk areas in the NFHL data (zones A and V and subclasses) and are classified as a "5" in the SHIRA relative hazard ranking scale of 1 to 5 (i.e., noting simply the presence of that hazard). Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and U.S. Territories.
column6: Federal Emergency Management Agency
column15: Present in areas with 1-percent annual chance (or 100-year) flood

column4: These data show areas susceptible to flooding based on USGS modeling of 30-meter digital elevation models, stream network lines, associated basins, flow direction grids, and National Water Model Maximum Flows for the last 20 years for all available flow lines. The geospatial input data used in the USGS flood modeling can be found in the National Hydrography Dataset (NHD Plus version 2). Areas are noted as "susceptible to flooding" and are classified as a "5" in the SHIRA relative hazard ranking scale of 1 to 5 (i.e., noting simply the presence of that hazard). Data are available for the conterminous United States.
column6: U.S. Geological Survey, Water Mission Area
column15: Present in areas with 1-percent annual chance (or 100-year) flood

column4: These data show subsidence susceptibility across the conterminous United States by identifying closed, surface depressions (sinkholes) in areas of karst or pseudo-karst geologic features. This hazard map was developed by the USGS National Cooperative Geologic Mapping Program, USGS Core Science Systems Mission Area, and the USGS Land Change Science Program. Data represent the density of closed, surface depressions (sinkholes) detected within a square kilometer polygon. The map only reflects sinkhole density in areas of karst or pseudo-karst geologic features. A Natural Breaks (Jenks) classification was used to translate the number of closed depression within each square kilometer into the following five classes: very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) subsidence susceptibility. Data are available for the conterminous United States.
column6: U.S. Geological Survey, Core Science Systems Mission Area

column4: These data show a prototype landslide hazard map of the conterminous United States that was developed by the USGS Landslide Hazards Program and originally published in 2012 as a journal article. The data is presented as 1-km grid cells, which denote the presence or absence of conditions that are favorable for landslides. Grid cells considered to have a landslide hazard were classified as a “5” on a relative 1 to 5 scale (i.e., noting simply the presence of that high hazard). Data are available for the conterminous United States.
column6: U.S. Geological Survey, Landslides Hazard Program
column9: Presence of Conditions Favorable for Landslides

column4: These data show areas of potential inundation from both local and distant tsunami sources, based on modeling done by State and Territorial agencies. The extent of potential tsunami inundation in each State, Territory, or Puerto Rico is based on modeling and scenario assumptions that were determined by individual state representatives. The type of hazard zone varies across the United States, such as specific scenarios (e.g., a local tsunami from a Cascadia earthquake in the U.S. Pacific Northwest or a distant tsunami from an Alaska-Aleutian earthquake hitting Hawaii) or probabilistic hazard zones (e.g., California). The original polygons were assigned a value of "5" on a relative hazard scale of 1 to 5 (i.e., simply noting the presence or absence of potential tsunami inundation). Data are available for the entirety of coastlines for conterminous U.S. states along the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, American Samoa, Guam, and the U.S. Virgin Islands. Data are available only for some coastal communities in Alaska, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands (CNMI), and states in the Gulf of Mexico region. An overview of completed and available tsunami hazard zones is made available by the U.S. National Tsunami Hazard Mitigation Program.
column6: U.S. Geological Survey, Western Geographic Science Center; Alaska Department of Natural Resources, Geological & Geophysical Surveys Division; Northeast States Emergency Consortium

column3: Tsunami - local event (point source, e.g., landslide, submarine landslide, volcano)

column4: These data show a combination of areas considered to contain some level of volcano threat, including lahar hazard zones (certain Alaska, Washington, Oregon, and California volcanoes), lava hazard zones (Big Island in Hawaii), and a 30-km buffer around all volcano peaks in the National Volcano Early Warning System (NVEWS) assessment. General information on volcano lahar and ash hazards, as well as volcano-specific hazard maps are available from the USGS Volcano Hazards Program. Original data came from USGS VHP researchers. Areas with lahar and lava hazards were classified as a “5” on a relative 1 to 5 scale (i.e. noting simply the presence of that high hazard). The 30-km buffers were assigned values of 1 to 5 based on their NVEWS threat level, including very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), and very high (bin 5). Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and U.S. Territories.
column6: U.S. Geological Survey, Volcano Hazards Program
column9: Modeled Proximal and Distal Hazard Zones
column15: Very High Threat (NVEWS) or Lahar/Lava Hazard Zone

column4: These data show the historic occurrence of National Weather Service (NWS) coldwave warnings from 2005 to 2021. Only one warning per county per day for the phenomena of Extreme Cold (EC) or Wind Chill (WC) are included in the analysis. Original data come from Iowa State University's Iowa Environmental Mesonet, which is an archive of NWS watches and warnings. Data are mapped at the county level and are classified using five equal interval bins to show historic occurrence across the United States. Counties are labelled as having a very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) number of NWS coldwave warnings during this time period. Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, and Hawaii.
column6: Mesonet, Iowa State University
column9: Number of Historic Events (equal interval bins)

column4: These data show the historic occurrence of drought for each week from 2000 to 2021. Only areas classified as moderate, severe, extreme, and exceptional are included in the analysis. Original data come from the Drought Monitor, which is produced jointly by the National Drought Mitigation Center (NDMC) at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), and the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA). Data are aggregated at approximately the county level and classified using five equal interval bins to show historic occurrence across the United States. Counties are labelled as having a very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) number of droughts during this time period. Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and U.S. Territories.
column6: National Drought Monitor, joint-produced by the National Drought Mitigation Center (University of Nebraska-Lincoln), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, U.S. Department of Agriculture
column9: Number of Historic Events (equal interval bins)

column4: These data show the historic occurrence of hail events from 1986 to 2020. Hail event criteria was a minimum of 0.75 inches prior to 2010 and a minimum of 1.00 inches after 2010. Original data come from NOAA's National Weather Service (NWS) Severe Weather Database. The original point data was screened to include only one hail event per 49-km grid cell (average county size) per day. Data are classified using five equal interval bins to show where there are concentrations across the United States. Grid cells are labelled as having a very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) number of hail events during this time period. Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and U.S. Territories.
column6: Severe Weather Database, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration National Weather Service
column9: Number of Historic Events (equal interval bins)

column4: These data show the historic occurrence of National Weather Service (NWS) extreme heat warnings from 1986 to 2021. Only one warning per county per day for the phenomena of excessive heat (EH) and heat (HT) are included in the analysis. Original data come from Iowa State University's Iowa Environmental Mesonet, which is an archive of NWS watches and warnings. Data are mapped at the county level and are classified using five equal interval bins to show historic occurrence across the United States. Counties are labelled as having a very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) number of NWS extreme heat warnings during this time period. Data are available for the conterminous United States.
column6: Mesonet, Iowa State University
column9: Number of Historic Events (equal interval bins)

column4: These data show modeled hurricane storm surge inundation for various storm categories based on the National Hurricane Center's hydrodynamic Sea, Lake, and Overland Surges from Hurricanes (SLOSH) model. Storm surge composites were created from SLOSH Maximum of Maximum envelopes of water (MOM) model outputs for Category 1 through 5 hurricanes. Original data came from NOAA's National Weather Service, National Hurricane Center. Data are mapped at the 1-km grid level. Grid cells note the minimum category storm (Category 1 through 5) to result in inundation within a cell. Data are available for the conterminous United States, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and U.S. Territories.
column6: National Hurricane Center and Central Pacific Hurricane Center
column9: Modeled Inundation based on Storm Category

column4: These data show the historic occurrence and paths of Atlantic and Pacific hurricanes from 1842 to 2021. This data includes any storms rated at Category 1 to 5. Original data come from NOAA's National Centers for Environmental Information International Best Track Archive for Climate Stewardship (IBTrACS) database. Data are mapped at the 1-km level and are classified using five equal interval bins to show where there are concentrations across the United States. Grid cells are labelled as having a very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) number of hurricane tracks during this time period. Data are available for the conterminous United States, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and U.S. Territories.
column6: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, National Centers for Environmental Information
column9: Number of Historic Events (equal interval bins)

column4: These data show the historic occurrence of damaging ice storms from 1946 to 2014. These storms delineate areas where ice sensitive structures (overhead lines, communication towers, and trees) were damaged. Original data come from the Army Corps of Engineers Cold Regions Research and Engineering Laboratory (CRREL). Data are mapped at the 1-km grid level and are classified using five equal interval bins to show historic occurrence across the United States. Grid cells are labelled as having a very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) number of damaging ice storm events during this time period. Data are available for the conterminous United States and Alaska.
column6: U.S Army Corps of Engineers, Cold Regions Research and Engineering Laboratory
column9: Number of Historic Events (equal interval bins)

column4: These data show the historic occurrence of lightning from 1987 to 2021 and represent the number of cloud-to-ground lightning flashes per grid cell (8km Albers Equal Area grid) per year. Original data come from NOAA's National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI). Data are resampled to a 1-km grid level and are classified using five equal interval bins to show where there are concentrations across the United States. Grid cells are labelled as having a very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) number of lightning events during this time period. Data are available for the conterminous United States and Alaska.
column6: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, National Centers for Environmental Information
column9: Number of Historic Events (equal interval bins)

column4: These data show the historic occurrence of National Weather Service (NWS) snow warnings from 2005 to 2021. Only one warning per county per day for the phenomena of blizzard (BZ), heavy snow (HS), lake effect snow (LE), or winter storm (WS) are included in the analysis. Original data come from Iowa State University's Iowa Environmental Mesonet, which is an archive of NWS watches and warnings. Data originally mapped at the county level are resampled to a 1-km grid and are classified using five equal interval bins to show areas with higher historic occurrence across the United States. Counties are labelled as having a very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) number of NWS snow warnings during this time period. Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, and Hawaii.
column6: Mesonet, Iowa State University
column9: Number of Historic Events (equal interval bins)

column4: These data show the historic occurrence of tornado touchdowns from 1986 to 2020. This hazard is a count of unique tornado touchdowns per day per county. Original data come from NOAA's National Weather Service, Storm Prediction Center. Data are mapped at the 1-km level and are classified using five equal interval bins to show where there are concentrations across the United States. Grid cells are labelled as having a very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) number of tornado touchdowns during this time period. Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and U.S. Territories.
column6: Severe Weather Database, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration National Weather Service
column9: Number of Historic Events (equal interval bins)

column3: Illness or injury of DOI employees - General
column4: These data show the historic occurrence of injury and illness events for DOI personnel from 2011 to 2021. Original data come from the DOI Safety Management Information System (SMIS) database. Data are mapped at the ZIP code level and are classified using five equal interval bins to show where there are concentrations of injuries or illnesses across the United States. ZIP code polygons are labelled as having a very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) number of injury or illness events for DOI personnel. Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and U.S. Territories.
column6: U.S. Department of Interior, Interior Office of the Solicitor
column9: Number of Historic Cases (equal interval bins)

column3: Illness of DOI employees - Viral Pandemic
column4: Geospatial data not available
column6: N/A

column4: These data show the number of high-priority, nonnative aquatic species from 1968 to 2021. Data came from the USGS Nonindigenous Aquatic Species (NAS) database, which was filtered through a web service API to only provide data of status noted as “established”, “collected”, or “unknown”; latitude and longitude accuracy of “accurate” or “approximate”; and certain species_ID numbers. Based on guidance from USGS subject matter experts, the following “high priority” species were queried in the NAS database: flowering rush, Northern Snakehead, Grass Carp, Grass Carp (diploid), Grass Carp (triploid), zebra mussel, quagga mussel, rusty crayfish, hydrilla, dioecious hydrilla, monoecious hydrilla, Silver Carp, Bighead Carp, American Bullfrog, Black Carp, Black Carp (diploid), Black Carp (triploid), Eurasian watermilfoil, Round Goby, starry stonewort, New Zealand mudsnail, Red Swamp Crayfish, giant salvinia, and water chestnut. This is a subset of the NAS database because some nonnative aquatic species (e.g. brown trout) are considered to be economically beneficial and are intentionally stocked in some waterbodies. High-priority NAS data were limited to records starting in 1968 because USGS subject matter experts believe older data have questionable accuracy and utility to managers. Data points were summarized at the HUC12 watershed level and then classified using five equal interval bins to show where there are concentrations across the United States. Watersheds are labelled as having a very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) number of high-priority, nonnative aquatic species. Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and U.S. Territories. For more information on nonnative aquatic species, please refer to the USGS Nonindigenous Aquatic Species program.
column6: U.S. Geological Survey, Nonindigenous Aquatic Species database
column9: Number of High-Priority Species Present (equal interval bins)

column4: These data show areas with a high likelihood of tree mortality due to major forest insects and diseases from 2013 to 2027. Original data come from the U.S. Forest Service’s National Insect and Disease Risk Map. Data are mapped on a 240m grid and all cells that contain areas with a high likelihood of tree mortality due to major forest insects and diseases are classified as a “5” in our 1 to 5 relative ranking scale. Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, and Hawaii.
column6: U.S. Department of Agriculture, U.S. Forest Service

column4: These data show the percent of terrestrial species in a county that are non-native. The percent values represent the number of species and subspecies of non-natives divided by the total number of species and subspecies in the county. Original data come from the USGS Biodiversity Information Serving Our Nation (BISON) database, which is a web-based Federal mapping resource for species occurrence data in the United States and its Territories. Data currently available through BISON are contributed by various U.S. Federal and State agencies, universities, and non-profit organizations, either directly to BISON or indirectly through their participation in the Global Biodiversity Information Facility. For this project, BISON data are mapped at the county level and are classified using five equal interval bins to show where there are concentrations across the United States. Counties are labelled as having a very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) percentage of terrestrial species in a county that are non-native. Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, and Hawaii.
column6: USGS Biodiversity Information Serving Our Nation (BISON) web application
column9: Percent of Species in a County that are Non-Native (equal interval bins)

column4: These data show the number of surface water pollutant discharge sites in a watershed, based on data obtained in February 2022. Original data were compiled from EPA's Facility Registry Service (FRS) National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) data along with Clean Watersheds Needs Survey (CWNS). Data are mapped at the watershed level (Hydrologic Unit Code 12) and are classified using five equal interval bins to show where there are concentrations of locations. Watersheds are labelled as containing a very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) number of surface water pollutant discharge sites. Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and U.S. Territories.
column6: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency via EPA Facility Registry Service (FRS)
column9: Number of Surface Water Pollutant Discharge Sites (equal interval bins)

column3: Toxicological - naturally occurring asbestos or erionite
column4: These data show naturally occurring asbestos and erionite, which can introduce public health issues (e.g., mesothelioma or other respiratory issues) if rocks and soils that may contain asbestos or erionite are disturbed by natural erosion or human activities. Certain geologic environments (e.g., ultramafic rocks, serpentinite, or fibrous amphibole) indicate favorable conditions for the occurrence of naturally occurring asbestos and these conditions have been mapped by the USGS for the conterminous United States. Erionite is a mineral series within the zeolite group and is classified as a Group 1 known respiratory carcinogen. Natural deposits of erionite, including fibrous forms, have been identified in the past in the western United States. The distribution of geologic occurrences of erionite in the United States shown in this map comes from a journal article by USGS researchers. Geospatial data on the potential distribution of naturally occurring asbestos and erionite were provided by USGS environmental researchers based on a compilation of state geological maps. Based on subject matter expert guidance, areas with weighting values of 8 to 10 in the original asbestos and erionite maps were considered to be a high hazard zone and were reclassified to a value of “5” for this project’s relative hazard scale (i.e. simply noting the high likelihood of presence). Data are available for the conterminous United States.
column6: U.S. Geological Survey, Ecosystem Mission Area

column4: Geospatial data not available
column6: N/A

column4: These data show naturally occurring arsenic (As), a potentially hazardous element that is found in soil and in many kinds of rocks. Because it is naturally occurring, there are normal levels of arsenic in air, water, soil, and food. Elevated levels of arsenic, however, can present a threat to human health. For more information on naturally occurring arsenic and potential health impacts, visit the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry (ATSDR), which includes a public health statement on arsenic. The map provided here shows naturally occurring arsenic in the top 0 to 5 cm of soil based on 2010 sampling. Original data come from a USGS national soil geochemistry database of elemental toxicants (conterminous United States, Alaska). Data are mapped with 1-km grid cells based on an inverse-distance-weighted interpolation of soil sampling points. Grid cells are then classified into five bins to characterize the relative hazard, including very low (bin value = 1 for < 2.7 parts per million, ppm), low (bin value = 2 for 2.7 - 4.3 ppm), moderate (bin value = 3 for 4.3 - 6.0 ppm), high (bin value = 4 for 6.0 - 8.3 ppm), and very high (bin value = 5 for 8.3 - 166 ppm), based on expert input to show where there are higher concentrations across the conterminous United States and Alaska.
column6: U.S. Geological Survey, Mineral Resources Program
column9: Relative Human-Health Threat Based on Soil Geochemistry

column4: These data show naturally occurring cadmium (Cd), a potentially hazardous element that is found in soil and many kinds of rocks. Elevated levels of cadmium, however, can present a threat to human health. For more information on naturally occurring cadmium and potential health impacts, visit the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry (ATSDR), which includes a public health statement on cadmium. The map shown here shows naturally occurring cadmium in the top 0 to 5 cm of soil based on 2010 sampling. Original data come from a USGS national soil geochemistry database of elemental toxicants (conterminous United States, Alaska). Data are mapped at with 1-km grid cells based on an inverse-distance-weighted interpolation of soil sampling points. Grid cells are then classified into 3 bins to characterize the relative threat, including low (bin value = 1 for < 0.2 parts per million, ppm), moderate (bin value = 3 for 0.2 - 0.4 ppm), and high (bin value = 5 for 0.4 - 6.0 ppm), based on expert input to show where there are higher concentrations across the conterminous United States and Alaska.
column6: U.S. Geological Survey, Mineral Resources Program
column9: Relative Human-Health Threat Based on Soil Geochemistry

column4: These data show naturally occurring lead (Pb), a potentially hazardous element that is found in soil and many kinds of rocks. Elevated levels of lead due to local geology or human activities can present a threat to human health. For more information on naturally occurring lead and potential health impacts, visit the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry (ATSDR), which includes a public health statement on lead. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention also have information on the human health impacts from lead exposure. The map shown here shows naturally occurring lead in the top 0 to 5 cm of soil based on 2010 sampling. Original data come from a USGS national soil geochemistry database of elemental toxicants (conterminous United States, Alaska). Data are mapped at with 1-km grid cells based on an inverse-distance-weighted interpolation of soil sampling points. Grid cells are then classified into 5 bins to characterize the relative threat, including very low (bin value = 1 for < 12.5 parts per million, ppm), low (bin value = 2 for 12.5 - 16.3 ppm), moderate (bin value = 3 for 16.3 - 20 ppm), high (bin value = 4 for 20 - 25.9 ppm), and very high (bin value = 5 for 25.9 - 541 ppm), based on expert input to show where there are higher concentrations across the conterminous United States and Alaska.
column6: U.S. Geological Survey, Mineral Resources Program
column9: Relative Human-Health Threat Based on Soil Geochemistry

column4: These data show naturally occurring selenium (Se), a potentially hazardous element that is found in soil and many kinds of rocks. Elevated levels of selenium, however, can present a threat to human health. For more information on naturally occurring selenium and potential health impacts, visit the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry (ATSDR), which includes a public health statement on selenium. The map shown here shows naturally occurring selenium in the top 0 to 5 cm of soil based on 2010 sampling. Original data come from a USGS national soil geochemistry database of elemental toxicants (conterminous United States, Alaska). Data are mapped at with 1-km grid cells based on an inverse-distance-weighted interpolation of soil sampling points. Grid cells are then classified into 3 bins to characterize the relative threat, including low (bin value = 1 for < 0.3 parts per million, ppm), moderate (bin value = 3 for 0.3 - 0.5 ppm), and high (bin value = 5 for 0.5 - 3.3 ppm), based on expert input to show where there are higher concentrations across the conterminous United States and Alaska.
column6: U.S. Geological Survey, Mineral Resources Program
column9: Relative Human-Health Threat Based on Soil Geochemistry

column4: These data show the predicted average indoor radon levels based on underlying geology from data compiled in 1992. Radon is a naturally occurring radioactive gas that can cause lung cancer. For more information, visit the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) website on radon. Original data come from an EPA map of radon zones. Data are mapped at the county level and are classified into three bins to show where there are higher concentrations across the United States based on average indoor radon screening levels. The relative radon threat for each county is labelled as low (bin value = 1 for screening levels less than 2 picocuries per liter, pCi/L), moderate (bin value = 3 for screening levels from 2 to 4 pCi/L), or high (bin value = 5 for screening levels greater than 4 pCi/L). Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, and Hawaii.
column6: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency

column4: These data show Valley Fever occurrences from 2000 to 2020. Valley Fever, also called coccidioidomycosis, is an infection caused by the fungus Coccidioides. The fungus is known to live in the soil in certain parts of the United States and Mexico. For more information on this infection, visit the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Valley Fever website. Original data come from various states' respective disease departments. New Mexico data for 2000-2005 was acquired through a request with the New Mexico Department of Health (NMDOH). Data are mapped at the county level and are classified using five equal interval bins to show where there are concentrations across the United States. Counties are labelled as having very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) occurrences of Valley Fever cases from 2000 to 2020. Data are only available for Arizona, California, New Mexico, Nevada, and Utah.
column6: Arizona Department of Health Services; California Department of Public Health; New Mexico Department of Health; Nevada Department of Health and Human Services; Utah Department of Health
column9: Number of Historic Cases (equal interval bins)

column4: These data show the historic occurrence (2000 - 2012) of Infectious Hematopoietic Necrosis (IHNV), which is a deadly viral disease that affects salmon and trout. Original data come from supplementary sampling data attached to a journal article by USGS researchers and academic partners. Data are mapped at the watershed level (HUC12) and are classified into five equal interval bins to show where there are concentrations across the United States. Watersheds are labelled as having a very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) concentration of IHNV occurrence. Data are available only for the Pacific Northwest states of Oregon, Washington, and Idaho. For more information on aquatic animal health, please refer to the USGS Western Fisheries Research Center and the Molecular Epidemiology of Aquatic Pathogens Infectious Hematopoietic Necrosis Virus (MEAP-IHNV) mapping application.
column6: Wiley Online Library, Ecological Society of America
column9: Number of IHNV Cases (equal interval bins)

column4: These data show the historic occurrence of years with reported Avian influenza events from 2004 to 2021. Original data come from the EMPRES database, which is a web-based application that has been designed to support veterinary services by facilitating the organization and access to regional and global disease information. The EMPRES-i database is a product of the Emergency Prevention System for Transboundary Animal and Plant Pests and Diseases (EMPRES) initiative led by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) of the United Nations. For this project, EMPRES-i data are mapped at the county level and are classified using four equal interval bins to show where there are concentrations across the United States. Counties are labelled as having a very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), or high (bin 4) number of years with reported cases of Avian influenza from 2004 to 2021. Data are available for the conterminous United States and Alaska.
column6: U.N. Food and Agriculture Organization, EMPRES Global Animal Disease Information System
column9: Number of Historic Cases (equal interval bins)

column4: These data show the historic occurrence of wildlife disease events (bacteria, fungus, parasite, toxin, and virus) from 1910 to 2021. Original data come the WHISPers database, which has been developed by the USGS National Wildlife Health Center. WHISPers stands for "Wildlife Health Information Sharing Partnership - event reporting system" and is a partner-driven, web-based repository for sharing basic information about historic and ongoing wildlife mortality (death) and morbidity (illness) events involving five or more wild animals. Data are mapped at the county level and are classified using five equal interval bins to show where there are concentrations across the United States. Counties are labelled as having a very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) number of wildlife disease events involving five or more animals. Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, Hawaii, and Puerto Rico.
column6: U.S. Geological Survey, Wildlife Health Information Sharing Partnership event reporting system (WHISPers) database
column9: Number of Historic Cases (equal interval bins)

column4: These data show the historic presence of chronic wasting disease, which is an emerging infectious disease that is fatal to free-ranging and captive animals in the deer family (Cervidae). Original data are from April 2022 and come from USGS researchers. Data are mapped at the county level and counties with historical presence of Chronic Wasting Disease are classified as a “5” in our 1 to 5 relative ranking scale. Data are available for the conterminous United States. The most up-to-date map of CWD can be found at the Chronic Wasting Disease Alliance.
column6: U.S. Geological Survey, National Wildlife Health Center
column15: Historical presence of Chronic Wasting Disease

column4: These data show a combination of data to identify areas more likely to contain Bacillius Anthracis, a naturally occurring soil pathogen that can cause anthrax. For more information on the public health risks associated with naturally occurring anthrax, visit the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's anthrax website. Original data used for this map (available here) are soil sampling sites across the conterminous United States and county occurrence data from a joint USGS/USEPA project. Average threshold values for the presence of various minerals (Calcium, Manganese, Phosphorus, and Strontium) in soil samples collected between 2000 and 2015 were used to estimate the susceptibility of soil to contain Bacillius Anthracis. Based on subject matter expert input, soil sampling sites were assigned a value of "1" for each mineral if the parts per million (ppm) was greater than 13000 ppm for Calcium, 463 ppm for Manganese, 580 ppm for Phosphorus, or 170 ppm for Strontium. Values for each site were added and sampling sites with higher values are considered to be more likely to contain Bacillius Anthracis. A grid with 500-meter cells was created from the sampling points across the conterminous United States using a natural neighbor interpolation. Values were then reclassified into a range from 0 (unlikely due to an absence of any mineral that exceeds the average threshold value) to 4 (highly likely because all four minerals exceed average threshold values). Finally, all cells within a county with historic occurrences of natural anthrax in soil samples were given a value of five, based on publicly available data.
column6: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and U.S. Geological Survey, St. Petersburg Coastal and Marine Science Center
column10: None (absence of any mineral that exceeds the average threshold value)
column11: One mineral that exceeds the average threshold value
column12: Two minerals that exceed the average threshold value
column13: Three minerals that exceed the average threshold value
column14: Four minerals that exceed the average threshold value

column4: Geospatial data not available
column6: N/A

column6: N/A

column4: These data show the historic occurrence (2003-2020) of human cases of mosquito-transmitted ("arboviral") diseases, including Chikungunya virus, Dengue fever, Eastern Equine encephalitis, Jamestown Canyon virus, Lacrosse virus, St. Louis encephalitis, West Nile virus, and Zika virus. Original data come from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) ArboNET. Data are mapped at the county level and are classified using five equal interval bins to show where there are concentrations across the United States. Counties are labelled as having a very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) number of reported arboviral disease cases. Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and U.S. Territories. Not all parts of the United States and Territories have recorded historical cases of any of the constituent diseases but these areas are included in the dataset's scope of analysis.
column6: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention ArboNET database
column9: Number of Historic Cases (equal interval bins)

column4: These data show the historic occurrence (2003-2020) of mosquito, bird, or veterinary cases of mosquito-transmitted ("arboviral") diseases, including Eastern Equine encephalitis, Jamestown Canyon virus, Lacrosse virus, St. Louis encephalitis, and West Nile virus. Original data come from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) ArboNET. Data are mapped at the county level and are classified using five equal interval bins to show where there are concentrations across the United States. Counties are labelled as having a very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) number of years of reported arboviral disease cases. Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and U.S. Territories. Not all parts of the United States and Territories have recorded historical cases of any of the constituent diseases but these areas are included in the dataset's scope of analysis.
column6: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention ArboNET database
column9: Number of Historic Cases (equal interval bins)

column4: These data show the historic occurrence of human cases of Rabies from 2008 to 2018. Original data come from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). For more information on this disease, visit the CDC Rabies page. Data are mapped at the county level and are classified using five equal interval bins to show where there are concentrations across the United States. Counties are labelled as having a very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) number of reported rabies cases. Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, and Puerto Rico.
column6: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column9: Number of Historic Cases (equal interval bins)

column4: These data show the historic occurrence of human cases of Lyme disease from 2000 to 2019. Original data come from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Data are mapped at the county level and are classified using five equal interval bins to show where there are higher concentrations across the United States. Counties are labelled as having very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) numbers of human cases of Lyme disease from 2000 to 2016. Data are available for the conterminous United States and Alaska.
column6: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column9: Number of Historic Cases (equal interval bins)

column4: These data show the historic occurrence of human cases of Powhassen Virus from 2004 to 2020. Original data come from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) ArboNET. For more information on this disease, visit the CDC Powhassen Virus page. Data are mapped at the county level and are classified using five equal interval bins to show where there are concentrations across the United States. Counties are labelled as having a very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) number of human cases of Powhassen Virus. Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and U.S. Territories. Not all parts of the United States and Territories have recorded historical cases of this disease, but these areas are included in the dataset’s scope of analysis.
column6: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention ArboNET database
column8: https://services3.arcgis.com/ZvidGQkLaDJxRSJ2/arcgis/rest/services (parent ArcGIS Server connection); https://services3.arcgis.com/ZvidGQkLaDJxRSJ2/ArcGIS/rest/services/DiseaseMaps_POW_PROD/FeatureServer (specific feature service connection); https://wwwn.cdc.gov/arbonet/Maps/ADB_Diseases_Map/index.html (viewer)
column9: Number of Historic Cases (equal interval bins)

column4: These data show the historic occurrence from 2000 to 2018 of human cases of several types of Rickettsial disease, including spotted fever rickettsiosis, ehrlichiosis caused by Ehrlichia chaffeensis and Ehrlichia ewingii, anaplasmosis, undetermined cases of ehrlichiosis or anaplasmosis, and Q Fever. Original data come from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). This map combines county level data summarized for each of the individual Rickettsial disease types. Data are mapped at the county level and are classified using five equal interval bins to show where there are concentrations across the United States. Counties are labelled as having a very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) number of reported human cases of these various Rickettsial diseases. Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, and Hawaii.
column6: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column9: Number of Historic Cases (equal interval bins)

column4: These data show the historic occurrence of human deaths due to certain water-borne diseases from 1999 to 2020. The dataset includes selected infectious and parasitic water-borne diseases coded as A00 to A09 in the detailed mortality data from the WONDERS database of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Data are mapped at the county level and are classified using five equal interval bins to show where there are concentrations across the United States. Counties are labelled as having a very low (bin 1), low (bin 2), moderate (bin 3), high (bin 4), or very high (bin 5) number of reported human deaths due to certain water-borne diseases. Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, and Hawaii.
column6: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, WONDER database
column9: Number of Historic Cases (equal interval bins)

column4: These data show points used to create 500-meter buffer zones around legacy contaminated sites associated with the U.S. Department of the Interior. Original data were provided by the Environmental Cleanup and Liability Management (ECLM) group within the DOI Office of Environmental Policy & Compliance and the Environmental Compliance and Cleanup division of the U.S. National Park Service. The data are organized by site name and contain columns that include latitude and longitude coordinates, as well as the Contaminants of Concern (CoCs) at each site. The database was cleaned to deal with inconsistencies in the latitude, longitude, and CoCs fields (e.g., multiple values in a single cell) and a geospatial point file was then created. Data are mapped as point locations and then buffered by 500 meters. Points and buffer zones are assigned a value of “5” in the SHIRA relative 1 to 5 rating scale to simply note the presence of a site. Data do not characterize the likelihood or extent of impacts if a contaminated site were impacted by another hazard that could spread contaminants (e.g., tsunami, flood, levee failure). Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and U.S. Territories.
column6: DOI Office of Environmental Policy and Compliance, Environmental Cleanup and Liability Management group; NPS Environmental Compliance and Cleanup Division

column3: Hazardous substance release - Flammable or toxic materials
column4: These data show points used to create 500-meter buffer zones around facilities that handle toxic or flammable materials, as identified by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency’s Toxics Release Inventory (TRI) Program and  Risk Management Plan (RMP) database. The Risk Management Plan Rule implements Section 112(r) of the 1990 Clean Air Act amendments and requires facilities that use extremely hazardous substances to develop a Risk Management Plan that is revised and resubmitted to the EPA every five years. Original data are point features that resulted from a query of geospatial EPA Facility Registry Service data for RMP data and TRI data. Data were downloaded in February 2022 and are mapped as point locations and then buffered by 500 meters. Points and buffer zones are assigned a value of “5” in the SHIRA relative 1 to 5 rating scale to simply note the presence of a site. Zones do not take into account variations in potential impacts (or area of impact) due to the type or amount of materials present. Data also do not characterize the likelihood of facility damage or the extent of material release if a facility were to fail. Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and U.S. Territories.
column6: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Risk Management Plan database

column4: These data show areas of potential inundation due to an upstream dam breach. Original data come from the U.S. Army Corp of Engineers Inland Electronic Navigational Charts (IENCs) and were accessed via the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) Secure Data portal. These data are not exhaustive for all dams in the United States and instead summarize a limited number of scenarios. This dataset represents the maximum potential inundation from model analysis for specific pool conditions and dam operational conditions that equate to established scenarios. Original data were polygons that delineated the areas of potential inundation. For this project, polygons are assigned the value of “5” in a 1 to 5 rating scale (i.e., noting simply the presence of potential inundation). Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, and Puerto Rico.
column6: U.S. Army Corps of Engineers via Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) Secure data portal

column4: These data show areas of potential inundation due to a failed levee, which is defined as an artificial embankment to contain or hold back water. Original data come from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) Inland Electronic Navigational Charts (IENCs) and were accessed via the USACE National Levee Database in March 2022. Original data were polygons that delineated the areas of potential inundation. For this project, polygons are assigned the value of “5” in a relative 1 to 5 rating scale (i.e., noting simply the presence of potential inundation). Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and U.S. Territories.
column6: U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, National Levee Database

column4: Geospatial data not available
column6: N/A

column4: These data show points used to create 500-meter buffer zones around the locations of solid waste landfill facilities that accept construction and demolition debris (along with transfer station facilities) circa 2012. Original data comes by extracting landfills from the EPA Facility Registry System (FRS) and including Transfer Stations. Landfills were identified based on NAICS and SIC codes. Data download is available at HIFLD Open. Data are mapped as point locations and then buffered by 500 meters. Points and buffer zones are assigned a value of “5” in the SHIRA relative 1 to 5 rating scale (i.e., to simply note the presence of a site). Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and U.S. Territories.
column6: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency via Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) Open data portal

column4: Geospatial data not available
column6: N/A

column4: These data show 500-meter buffer zones around all oil- or gas-related datasets available from the U.S. Department of Homeland Security Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) Open Data portal, including facilities for just natural gas (LNG terminals, NG compressor stations, NG import and export sites, LNG pipelines, NG market hubs, NG processing plants, NG receipt delivery points, NG storage facilities, non-gasoline alternative fueling stations), facilities just for oil (oil refineries, pipelines), and facilities that handle oil and natural gas (oil and NG platforms, oil and NG interconnects, oil and NG wells). Original data are displayed as point or line features and then buffered by 500 meters in order to identify any asset within 500 meters of oil or gas infrastructure. Data simply show the presence of infrastructure and do not characterize the likelihood of failure or the extent of damages if infrastructure were to fail. Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, and Hawaii.
column6: U.S. Energy Information Administration and Oak Ridge National Laboratory via Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Program (HIFLD) Open data portal; Platts and Oak Ridge National Laboratory via HSIP Gold 2015; U.S. Department of Energy Alternative Fuels Data Center
column7: None except Restricted for oil/natural gas pipelines; natural gas liquid pipelines.

column4: Geospatial data not available
column6: N/A

column4: These data show points used to create 500-meter buffer zones around facilities that the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulates for radiation and radioactivity, as noted in the Radiation Information (RADInfo) Database, which is part of the EPA Facility Registry Service (FRS) and can be publicly downloaded. Data were downloaded in February 2022 and are displayed as point locations, and for exposure analysis the point locations are buffered by 500 meters to identify any DOI asset within 500 meters of a site containing radiological substances. Data are available for the conterminous United States and Hawaii.
column6: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Facility Registry Service (FRS)

column4: These data show the locations of hazardous waste sites in the U.S as defined by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) National Priorities List Superfund sites in 2022. Original data comes from the Data.gov data repository via the EPA. Data are mapped as polygons and assigned a value of “5” in the SHIRA relative scale of 1-5 (i.e., to simply note the presence of a site). Data are available for the conterminous United States, Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and U.S. Territories.
column6: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, National Priorities List (NPL)
